case.name: Purchas, in the matter of Worldwide Workers Pty Limited (in liq) [2006] FCA 1223 (8 September 2006)

citphrases.citphrase: whether funds held pursuant to terminated deed of company arrangement are held for the benefit of deed creditors or property of the company in liquidation
direction that the funds be administered as the property of the company in liquidation
whether deed terminated by force of s.445c(c)
where "circumstances" are "payment to all admitted creditors of the dividend"
whether funds held pursuant to terminated deed of company arrangement are held for the benefit of deed creditors or property of the company in liquidation
direction that the funds be administered as the property of the company in liquidation corporations
application by liquidators/former administrators for increase in remuneration as administrators

citances.sentence: 21 The deed draws a distinction between "the Funds" (as defined) and "the Company's property" (undefined). I doubt that this is intended to indicate that "the Funds" are not property of the company (cf Federal Commissioner of Taxation v All Suburbs Car Repairs Pty Ltd [1994] FCA 1393 ; (1994) 14 ACSR 753 ; Lombe v Wagga Leagues Club Ltd [2006] NSWSC 3 ; (2006) 56 ACSR 387 ; Re Purchas; Estore Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1222 ; (2006) 154 FCR 246 ; Purchas; Worldwide Workers Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1223). The indication is, rather, that such property of the company as is not within either of the two designated funds is to be dealt with, together with the property within the funds, in the ways specified in relation to "the Company's property and the Funds" --- while property within a particular fund (but not other property) is to be dealt with in the ways specified in relation to that fund.

The material facts in Purchas, in the matter of Estore Pty Limited (in liq) [2006] FCA 1222 and Purchas, in the matter of Worldwide Workers Pty Limited (in liq) [2006] FCA 1223 are indistinguishable in substance from this case. Directions will be given and an order for costs will be made for the same reasons as those appearing in the aforementioned cases.

legistitles.title: CORPORATIONS ACT 2001
CORPORATIONS ACT 2001 - SECT 436A Company may appoint administrator if board thinks it is or will become insolvent
